awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Shock interaction with a complex hydrodynamic medium
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Vorobieff, Peter / Jacobs, Gustaaf
Proposal Number: 1603915 / 1603326

When a gas moves at high speeds, a pressure shock is often formed. A comprehensive study that involves experiments and computations is proposed for the case when small particles are also present. Practical applications of the proposed work are found in a plethora of engineering technologies that involve mixing, such as supersonic and hypersonic combustion, and dust explosions (in coal mines and in grain or sugar silos). A better understanding of the basic physics of shock-driven mixing will lead to improved designs in the energy area, reducing use of natural resources and impact on the environment.

It is proposed to study shock-driven instabilities in particle-laden flows, where large-scale density gradients are present in the gas phase simultaneously with presence of the particle phase, and the latter may account for a significant fraction of the volume-averaged density. The proposed effort aims to overcome the current disconnect between the studies of the purely hydrodynamic features of shock-driven media (Richtmyer-Meshkov instabilities (RMI), secondary instabilities, and transition to turbulence) and multiphase features of the same flows. By combining computational analysis, experiment and theoretical and model developments, a benchmark set will be developed to prepare for a detailed investigation of the relevant physics, not just in terms of gross flow behavior, but with focus on subtler mixing phenomena induced by baroclinic and particle-gas interaction mechanisms. Experiments will be conducted in the University of New Mexico shock tube, one of the most advanced research facilities of this type in the world. It has a design Mach number of 4 and a highly modular architecture allowing to study shock interaction with a wide variety of objects with minimal reconfiguration. Computations will be conducted with Eulerian-Lagrangian and Eulerian-Eulerian codes based on higher-order Weighted-Essentially-Non-Oscillatory (WENO) schemes that have been developed by the PI at SDSU. The codes will be validated for the interaction of shock and cloud of particles. Effects on flow morphology caused by non-uniformities in the seeding and particle size distribution will be determined. Three-dimensional computations of the complete system and experiment will provide insight into the fully non-linear flow development. The work will engage students from underrepresented groups, encouraging them to pursue long-term careers in STEM-related fields.

por.por_cntn:
Shock-driven instabilities in particle-laden flows with density gradients in the gas phase as well as the particle phase were studied. The goal of the effort was to overcome the current disconnect between the studies of the purely hydrodynamic features of shock-driven media (Richtmeyer-Meshkov instabilities, secondary instabilities and transition to turbulence) and multiphase features of the same flows.  A computational analysis, and theoretical and model developments were combined with experiment to establish a benchmark that sets the stage for a detailed investigation of not just gross flow behavior, but subtler mixing phenomena induced by baroclinic and particle-gas interaction mechanisms.

 

Simulations of the dynamics of a particle curtain in the accelerated flow behind a normal shock were conducted. The effect of perturbed and random initial curtain conditions on the particle dynamics and dispersion were investigated and showed that the growth rate of the perturbation is driven by the relative velocity difference in the particle phase. The growth rate closely follows the theory of Richtmeyer and Meshkov for an equivalent mixture Atwood number. Simulations were compared against shock tube experiments on the interaction between a normal shock and a cloud of silicon particles. A simple first order model was found to accurately determine curtain acceleration statistics and shock/expansion locations. Models were developed that capture the interaction of the subcloud particle dynamics through Reynolds-stress equivalent correlations. Based on kinematic consideration the averaged cloud motion and dispersion were modeled through principle strains and stresses. Multi-scale models that homogenize the results of high-resolution simulation of a small cloud of particles provided necessary closure terms for the Reynolds stress equivalent term. The models provide insight into straining of particle clouds and curtain when interacting with a shock.

Shock-driven multiphase phenomena are important for a variety of compelling reasons, such as the need to understand fundamental processes on scales from planetary to astrophysical, for example, supernova explosions and their interactions with clouds of cosmic dusty gas and plasma. On the smaller scale lie many practical problems, including fuel injection in scramjets and explosions of coal dust in mines. Engineers have few available tools to aid in the modeling of compressible multiphase flow with shocks. The information determined from the investigation can be used to improve existing models. Undergraduate and graduate students from the Mathematics Engineering Science Achievement (MESA) program at SDSU, one of the country's most successful programs of its kind, were actively involved in the project activities.

Modified by: Gustaaf Jacobs
